title: Warren Openly Opposes Second Term for Powell as Fed Chief; Powell Urges Raising U.S. Debt Limit
text:
Top News

Warren Says She Will Vote Against Second Term for Fed's Powell

Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.) said Tuesday she would oppose a second term for Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell if President Biden nominates the central bank leader, highlighting the intra-party divide over his candidacy.

Ms. Warren told Mr. Powell during a congressional hearing that his efforts to loosen financial regulations imposed after the 2008 financial crisis "makes you a dangerous man to head the Federal Reserve."

U.S. Economy

U.S. Economy Set to Pick Up Speed After Delta-Driven Downturn

The Delta variant of Covid-19 appeared to temper economic growth this summer, but economists expect the recovery from the pandemic to reaccelerate as the virus's toll eases.

Consumer Confidence Continues Slide on Covid-19, Inflation Worries

Home-Price Growth Hit Record in July

The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures average home prices in major metro areas, rose 19.7% in the year that ended in July, the highest annual rate of price growth since the index began in 1987.

Yellen Says Treasury Could Exhaust Cash Reserves by Oct. 18

Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen told Congress the Treasury would be unable to pay all of the government's bills if lawmakers don't raise the federal borrowing limit, citing limited resources that would be depleted quickly.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell also urged lawmakers to raise the debt limit, saying a crisis-management playbook Fed officials put together during a similar standoff in 2013, which some analysts believe could guide the central bank's response this fall if the federal government can't pay all its bills, shouldn't lead lawmakers to conclude the Fed could fully offset a financial catastrophe.

Republicans Block Democrats' Latest Effort to Advance Debt-Ceiling Bill

Debt-Ceiling Standoff Distorts Short-Term Treasury Market

Progressives Split on Backing Thursday's House Infrastructure Vote

The Debt Ceiling: What to Know

Key Developments Around the World

With Germany Sidelined, EU Must Wait on Big Challenges

As the European Union's largest member, Germany inevitably helps shape the bloc's plans, and in coming months the EU must decide whether to loosen budget rules for members, a change that could affect its economic trajectory.

Bank of Thailand Keeps Rate Unchanged at Record Low

The Bank of Thailand said its policy committee voted unanimously to hold its one-day repurchase rate unchanged at 0.5%. Daily Covid-19 infections in the country peaked in August and have declined in recent weeks.

OPEC Predicts a Winner in Global Energy Transition: OPEC

The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is forecasting an unlikely winner amid an energy shift away from hydrocarbons: cartel members, as global oil demand will grow steadily over the next two decades.

U.S. and Europeans Parley in Pittsburgh on Tech, Trade and China

A high-level trade and technology meeting set for Pittsburgh on Wednesday is aimed at smoothing over squabbles between the U.S. and European Union, even as policy disagreements over China threaten to further strain relations.

Financial Regulation Roundup

Bank Mergers May Hit Their Highest Level Since the Financial Crisis

Banks have announced more than $54 billion in deals through late September, putting industry mergers and acquisitions on pace for their biggest year since 2008, when some big banks had to sell themselves to stave off collapse.

SEC Taps Dan Berkovitz to Serve as General Counsel

The SEC has hired a former aide to Chairman Gary Gensler as its top lawyer. Dan Berkovitz, who is stepping down as a commissioner at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, will join the SEC as general counsel on Nov. 1.

Commentary

What if Inflation Is Here to Stay?

If structural changes turn out to be the main cause of the current rise in inflation, Americans shouldn't expect the consequences—higher prices at the store—to be "transitory," William A. Galston writes.

Basis Points

A shortfall in global energy supplies spilled into crude markets on Tuesday, pushing oil prices to their highest levels in three years.

Goldman Sachs cut its China growth forecast, citing the country's power crunch, now expecting zero gross domestic product growth in the third quarter. (Barrons.com)

German consumer sentiment is expected to strengthen in October, reaching its highest level for the last year and a half, according to market-research group GfK, whose forward-looking consumer sentiment index forecasts confidence among households rising from minus 1.1 points in September to 0.3 point next month. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expect a decline to minus 1.9 points. (Dow Jones Newswires)

The French consumer confidence index rose to 102 in September from 99 in August, suggesting households don't share business leaders' fear of demand-crushing supply-side constraints and a new surge in Covid-19 cases, Pantheon Macroeconomics said. (DJN)

Sweden's August retail sales were better than expected, rising 0.7% on the month and 6.6% on the year, as sales of both durable goods and non-durables rose, said Nordea. Retail sales are below the very high level seen before the summer, but are nevertheless still at a strong, high level, it added. (DJN)

Switzerland's Federal Finance Administration has lowered the country's planned capital market funding for 2021, due to expected lower financing needs related to the Covid-19 pandemic. It now sees Switzerland's bond issuance at 8 billion Swiss francs ($8.64 billion) at face value this year, down CHF2 billion versus March 30 estimates. (DJN)

Ecuador's business-friendly government is calling on Washington to sign a free-trade deal to stem rising immigration to the U.S. "The entire issue is about creating jobs in Ecuador so that people don't migrate," said Ivonne Baki, Ecuador's ambassador to the U.S. (DJN)
